study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how sleep restriction combined with calorie restriction affects glucose regulation, insulin sensitivity, and lipoprotein subclass particles during weight loss.
results_summary: Sleep restriction influenced lipoprotein subclass particles and glucose regulation, with differential changes in glucagon concentration (decreased in calorie restriction alone but unchanged with sleep restriction) and a decrease in mean HDL particle size only in the sleep restriction group. Visfatin concentrations showed no significant changes in either group.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (75% female, BMI 31.4–34.5 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction of 30–90 minutes less than habitual time-in-bed, 5 days per week, with 2 ad libitum sleep days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction therapy (SRT) modifies sleep pressure and arousal, providing mechanistic evidence for its effectiveness in treating insomnia.
results_summary: The study found that SRT increased sleep pressure (evidenced by enhanced sleepiness and reduced psychomotor vigilance) and decreased arousal (evidenced by lower cognitive arousal and reduced beta power) compared to the control intervention. These effects were observed during acute implementation and persisted at follow-up.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-55 meeting DSM-5 criteria for insomnia disorder (56 participants, 39 females, mean age 40.78 ± 9.08).
effective_dosage: Not specified (time in bed restriction details not provided).
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention with a 12-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of short-term sleep restriction on subjective and physiological parameters in middle-aged adults and assess recovery after rest.
results_summary: Sleep restriction increased sleepiness, fatigue, stress, cortisol, and TSH while reducing T4, T3, and CRP. All parameters returned to baseline levels after recovery.
population_specificity: 118 healthy middle-aged adults (35-44 years) without sleep problems (59 men, 59 women).
study_duration: 3 days of sleep restriction followed by 4 days of recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of partial sleep restriction on anxiety symptoms, particularly repetitive negative thinking (RNT) and obsessions, and whether prior sleep efficiency moderates these effects.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (4 hours) was associated with decreased inhibition and increased RNT and obsessions. Those with lower pre-restriction sleep efficiency showed the highest post-restriction anxiety symptoms.
population_specificity: Healthy sleeping adults (n=73).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the causal effect of sleep restriction on blood pressure and assess whether psychological distress mediates this relationship.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (1.5 hours less per night) increased systolic blood pressure, wake ambulatory diastolic blood pressure, and mean arterial pressure, but psychological distress did not mediate these effects.
population_specificity: 237 women in a community-based cohort, with 24 completing a randomized crossover intervention (age 30.2 ± 6.5 years, BMI 24.3 ± 2.8 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Sleep reduced by 1.5 hours per night.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether time in bed (TIB) restriction is the central mechanism through which sleep restriction therapy (SRT) improves sleep consolidation and reduces insomnia symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that SRT significantly reduced insomnia severity compared to time in bed regularization (TBR), with robust improvements in sleep continuity and quality of life, both objectively and subjectively measured. The effects were sustained at 12 weeks post-randomization.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-55 diagnosed with insomnia disorder (56 participants, 39 females, mean age 40.78 ± 9.08).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved prescribed TIB restriction vs. regularization).
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nurse-delivered sleep restriction therapy (SRT) is clinically and cost-effective compared to sleep hygiene advice for treating insomnia disorder in primary care.
results_summary: The study will assess the effectiveness of SRT using the Insomnia Severity Index at 6 months, along with secondary outcomes like sleep-related quality of life, depressive symptoms, and work productivity. Results could support broader implementation of nurse-delivered SRT in primary care.
population_specificity: Adults with insomnia disorder recruited from primary care in England.
effective_dosage: 4 weekly sessions, totaling approximately 1 hour of therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sleep restriction (SR) during stroke recovery on neurorepair, specifically focusing on CD169+ macrophages infiltration, neurogenesis, and functional recovery.
results_summary: SR increased CD169+ macrophages infiltration into the ischemic brain parenchyma but inhibited neurogenesis and functional recovery. Dexmedetomidine treatment during SR reversed these negative effects by promoting CD169+ macrophages infiltration and neurogenesis.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to cerebral ischemia followed by reperfusion.
effective_dosage: 20 hours of sleep deprivation per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sleep Restriction Therapy (SRT) increases the risk of excessive sleepiness compared to Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) and a sleep education control.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in excessive sleepiness risk between SRT and CBT-I, suggesting SRT is as safe as CBT-I in this regard. Both treatments showed comparable odds of excessive sleepiness, indicating SRT may be a viable alternative to CBT-I.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (56.44 ± 5.64 years) with perimenopausal or postmenopausal onset of DSM-5 insomnia disorder.
effective_dosage: SRT (2 sessions with interim phone contact); CBT-I (6 sessions).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but assessments were performed at pretreatment and posttreatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of sleep restriction on myofibrillar protein synthesis (MyoPS) and whether high-intensity interval exercise (HIIE) could counteract potential negative effects.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (4 hours per night for five nights) reduced MyoPS, but performing HIIE during this period maintained MyoPS at control levels. The study suggests HIIE may mitigate sleep-loss-induced muscle mass reductions.
population_specificity: 24 healthy, young men matched for age, V̇O2peak, BMI, and habitual sleep duration.
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction (4 hours time in bed per night) with or without three sessions of HIIE.
study_duration: Five nights of sleep restriction following two baseline nights.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction therapy alone could improve depressive symptoms in individuals with both insomnia and depression.
results_summary: Two out of six patients showed clinical improvement in depressive symptoms post-treatment, while all six showed meaningful improvement at 3-month follow-up. Two patients maintained gains at 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Seven patients (six completed) with both insomnia and depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the time course of decline in bone formation marker (P1NP) during sleep restriction with concurrent circadian disruption.
results_summary: Plasma P1NP levels declined significantly within the first 10 days of sleep restriction and remained lower than baseline with prolonged exposure, suggesting adverse effects on bone metabolism. Bone resorption marker (CTX) levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Nine men aged 20-59 years.
effective_dosage: ~5.6 hours of sleep per 24 hours during the forced desynchrony segment.
study_duration: ~3 weeks (5 days baseline, followed by forced desynchrony).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects and recovery needs of short-term sleep restriction versus intermittent sleep fragmentation on cognition, performance, and health.
results_summary: Sleep restriction resulted in less wake time, less light and REM sleep, but more deep sleep compared to fragmentation. Recovery effects were stronger after restriction, with subjective sleep quality reduced after both interventions but recovering significantly only after restriction. PVT performance showed slight recovery post-restriction.
population_specificity: 20 healthy male participants (mean age 39.9 ± 7.4 years, mean BMI 25.5 ± 2.2 kg/m²).
study_duration: Two weeks per condition (baseline, intervention, two recovery nights).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a multi-component cognitive behavioral self-help intervention (MCT) and a sleep restriction intervention (SRT) against care as usual (CAU) for treating insomnia.
results_summary: Both MCT and SRT were more effective than CAU in reducing insomnia severity, with medium to large effect sizes, and maintained gains at six-month follow-up. MCT participants reported higher satisfaction than SRT participants, though efficacy differences between the two active conditions were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adults with insomnia but no comorbid psychiatric disorders (N = 104).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction therapy (SRT) improves daytime function and quality of life in postmenopausal women with insomnia and whether it is as effective as cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTI).
results_summary: SRT produced moderate-to-large improvements in fatigue, energy, sleepiness, and work function, comparable to CBTI, though CBTI showed superior benefits in emotional wellbeing. Both interventions improved quality of life and work performance.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (56.44 ± 5.64 years) with perimenopausal or postmenopausal onset or exacerbation of chronic insomnia.
study_duration: Posttreatment and 6-month follow-up assessments (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of three days of sleep restriction on maximal jump performance, joint coordination, and cognitive response time in elite cyclists.
results_summary: Sleep restriction decreased maximal jump performance, increased joint coordination variability, and was associated with slower response times, suggesting potential negative impacts on athletic performance and injury risk.
population_specificity: Eleven elite cyclists
effective_dosage: Sleep restricted to 4 hours per night

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of partial sleep restriction on emotional regulation through cognitive reappraisal using fMRI.
results_summary: Sleep restriction decreased self-reported regulation success to negative stimuli in young participants, with no significant effects on brain activity or connectivity in either age group. The study did not support the idea of a prefrontal-amygdala disconnect after sleep restriction.
population_specificity: Young (age 20-30) and older (age 65-75) participants.
study_duration: One night of normal sleep and one night of restricted sleep.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of sleep restriction on metabolism-related parameters, including hunger, appetite-regulating hormones, brain activity, energy intake and expenditure, weight change, and insulin sensitivity.
results_summary: Sleep restriction significantly increased subjective hunger and daily calorie intake, led to weight gain, decreased insulin sensitivity, and altered brain activity in response to food stimuli, but did not strongly affect leptin or ghrelin levels or energy expenditure.
population_specificity: Not specified (participants in 41 randomized controlled trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a Drosophila model for sleep restriction therapy (SRT) to investigate its neurobiological basis and potential benefits in aging and Alzheimer's disease models.
results_summary: Sleep restriction improved sleep efficiency in short-sleeping Drosophila mutants and reversed sleep impairments in aging and Alzheimer's disease models, leading to enhanced reproductive fitness and extended lifespan. The response required ongoing environmental inputs but was independent of the molecular circadian clock.
population_specificity: Drosophila (fruit fly) mutants, including aging and Alzheimer's disease models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neural mechanisms of sleep restriction by examining its impact on cerebral glucose metabolism during NREM sleep in individuals with primary insomnia and good sleepers.
results_summary: Acute sleep restriction led to lower relative rCMRglc in specific brain regions during recovery NREM sleep, with no significant group differences between insomnia patients and good sleepers. Sleep quality improved in insomnia patients after sleep restriction, and whole-brain glucose metabolism decreased in good sleepers but not in insomnia patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with primary insomnia (n=17) and good sleepers (n=19).
study_duration: One night of partial or total sleep restriction

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the proposed mechanisms-of-action of Sleep Restriction Therapy (SRT) for treating insomnia, focusing on homeostatic sleep pressure, hyperarousal, circadian regulation, and sleep variability.
results_summary: Most studies reported reduced time in bed and decreased sleep onset latency, suggesting increased sleep pressure, but evidence for reduced arousal and sleep variability was limited and derived from uncontrolled studies. No changes in circadian phase or periodicity were observed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general insomnia population inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction therapy (SRT) is as effective as multicomponent cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTI) in treating menopause-related chronic insomnia.
results_summary: SRT significantly reduced insomnia severity (ISI decreased by 6.56 points) and had higher remission rates (38%-57%) compared to sleep hygiene education, though CBTI showed slightly better outcomes in sleep maintenance and remission likelihood.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (56.44 ± 5.64 years) with chronic DSM-5 insomnia disorder related to menopause.
study_duration: Not specified (assessed at posttreatment and 6-month follow-up)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction therapy (SRT) improves depressive symptoms, maladaptive thinking, and somatic hyperarousal in postmenopausal women with insomnia, and whether it is as effective as cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTI).
results_summary: SRT produced moderate reductions in depressive symptoms, though these improvements were delayed until six months posttreatment. It also led to large improvements in dysfunctional beliefs about sleep and moderate improvements in presleep somatic arousal, but had weaker effects on cognitive arousal, rumination, and worry.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (56.34 ± 5.41 years) with peri- or postmenopausal onset of chronic insomnia.
study_duration: Not specified (assessed at baseline, posttreatment, and six-month follow-up)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep duration causally affects sleepiness, inattention, and behavioral functioning in adolescents with ADHD.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (6.5 hours) increased parent-reported inattention and oppositional symptoms, as well as daytime sleepiness and sluggish cognitive tempo (SCT) reported by both parents and adolescents, compared to sleep extension (9.5 hours). No effects were found for parent-reported hyperactivity-impulsivity, adolescent-reported ADHD inattention, or CPT performance.
population_specificity: 72 adolescents aged 14-17 years with ADHD, narrowed to 48 with complete actigraphy data.
study_duration: 3 weeks (1 stabilization week, 1 week restriction, 1 week extension).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the homeostatic response to chronic sleep restriction (6 hr time in bed) and extension (10 hr time in bed) and subsequent total sleep deprivation in healthy participants.
results_summary: Sleep restriction primarily reduced REM sleep, while SWA and SWE were minimally affected. The SWA response aligned with the two-process model, showing no significant adaptation during chronic restriction or extension.
population_specificity: 35 healthy participants in a cross-over design.
effective_dosage: 6 hr (restriction) and 10 hr (extension) time in bed per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the objective and subjective daytime consequences of Sleep Restriction Therapy (SRT) during its acute phase in adults with Chronic Insomnia Disorder.
results_summary: Participants maintained similar total sleep time from pre- to post-treatment, with no significant changes in daytime sleepiness or objective performance on reaction time and driving tasks. The findings suggest SRT does not cause significant impairments in sleepiness or reaction times during the acute phase.
population_specificity: 16 adults (12 females, 4 males) aged 36.3 ± 13.4 years diagnosed with Chronic Insomnia Disorder.
effective_dosage: Not specified (time in bed restriction based on Miller et al., 2014 recommendations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of chronic sleep restriction (CSR) on dendritic lengths and spines in the CA1 hippocampus and assess whether curcumin (CUR) could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Chronic sleep restriction reduced dendritic length by 39% and decreased spine density (stubby, thin, and mushroom spines by 38%, 33%, and 32%, respectively). CUR treatment protected against dendritic shortening and loss of stubby and mushroom spines but not thin spines.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of sleep restriction combined with circadian disruption on bone biomarkers, focusing on bone turnover and osteocyte function.
results_summary: The study found that 3 weeks of sleep restriction with circadian disruption led to decreased bone formation (P1NP) but no change in bone resorption (CTX), with younger men showing a greater reduction in P1NP and increased sclerostin levels.
population_specificity: 10 men (6 aged 20-27 years, 4 aged 55-65 years).
effective_dosage: 5.6 hours of sleep per 24 hours with a recurring 28-hour "day" in dim light.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify common cerebral pathways in sleep restriction and Neuropeptide S (NPS) action to counteract sleep restriction's effect on short-term memory.
results_summary: Sleep restriction impaired short-term memory and reduced neuronal activation in the cingulate cortex, while NPS injection reversed these deficits and increased activation in the infralimbic cortex. Sleep restriction did not affect anxiety-like behavior or neural activation in the amygdala and ventral hippocampus.
population_specificity: C57-Bl/6J male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sleep restriction (SR) on hepatic metabolic profiles in rats, focusing on NAD metabolism, methionine metabolism, and TCA cycle intermediates.
results_summary: The study found distinctive metabolic changes in the liver due to SR, including NAD accumulation, upregulation of Nampt, elevated SAM:SAH ratio (indicating increased methylation potential), and alterations in TCA cycle intermediates and Acly gene expression, suggesting decreased TCA activity and increased lipogenesis.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to 5 days of sleep restriction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic sleep restriction increases brain vulnerability to amyloid-β oligomers (AβOs) and whether pro-inflammatory mediators contribute to memory impairment in sleep-restricted mice.
results_summary: Chronic sleep restriction increased brain expression of pro-inflammatory mediators, reduced synaptic marker proteins, and heightened susceptibility to AβOs-induced memory impairment. Memory impairment in sleep-restricted mice was prevented by TNF-α neutralization with infliximab.
population_specificity: Mice (animal study)
effective_dosage: Sub-toxic dose of AβOs (1pmol, single intracerebroventricular infusion)
study_duration: Chronic sleep restriction (specific duration not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of acute sleep deprivation on glucose tolerance in rats to understand the mechanisms linking sleep curtailment to impaired glucose metabolism.
results_summary: Sleep deprivation impaired glucose tolerance and reduced early-phase insulin responses to a glucose challenge, regardless of the time of day. Basal glucose, insulin, and corticosterone levels remained unchanged, indicating that short sleep restriction during rest phases promotes glucose intolerance by attenuating insulin response.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of sleep restriction on local immune function and skin barrier restoration, and whether nutritional supplementation could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Sleep restriction delayed skin barrier recovery and reduced local immune responses (lower IL-8 levels). Nutritional supplementation improved cytokine responses (higher IL-6 and IL-8 levels) but did not significantly affect wound healing rate.
population_specificity: Healthy adults
effective_dosage: 1.5 g·kg-1·day-1 protein supplemented with arginine, glutamine, zinc sulfate, vitamin C, vitamin D3, and omega-3 fatty acids vs. 0.8 g·kg-1·day-1 protein without supplements
study_duration: 72 hours of sleep restriction (2-hour nightly sleep)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to experimentally assess the impact of sleep restriction on affective functioning in adolescents, including socioaffective behavior in peer interactions.
results_summary: Sleep restriction increased negative affect (self-reported and pupil response) and negative affective behavior in peer interactions, while positive affect showed mixed or non-significant effects.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 11.5-15.0 (Study 1) and 12-15.0 (Study 2).
effective_dosage: 4 hours in bed (restriction) vs. 10 hours in bed (extension).
study_duration: Two nights per condition, with a one-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining physical activity counseling with sleep restriction therapy (PASR) was more effective than sleep restriction therapy alone (SR) in improving physical activity levels and sleep quality in patients with chronic insomnia.
results_summary: The PASR group showed greater improvements in physical activity levels, daily steps, sleepiness, fatigue, and sleep efficiency compared to the SR group, with statistically significant results (P<0.05). The study concluded that PASR effectively increased physical activity and improved sleep quality in chronic insomnia patients.
population_specificity: Outpatients with chronic insomnia (n=71).
effective_dosage: Four weekly sessions of sleep restriction therapy (SR) or PASR (SR + physical activity counseling based on the 5A model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of experimental sleep restriction on attention and hyperactivity outcomes in youth.
results_summary: Sleep-restricted youth had significantly worse attention outcomes compared to those with extended sleep, but no differences were found in hyperactivity. Age and sex were significant moderators of the effect on attention.
population_specificity: Youth (N = 496 across 17 independent samples)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether experimental sleep restriction affects experimentally induced pain and pain-elicited EEG responses.
results_summary: Sleep restriction increased subjective pain ratings for high-intensity stimuli, heightened pain-elicited EEG responses, and reduced pressure pain thresholds, but did not affect habituation patterns.
population_specificity: Self-reported healthy volunteers (n = 21, age 18-31 years).
study_duration: 2 nights of sleep restriction and 2 nights of habitual sleep (crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether simplified sleep restriction (SSR) could effectively improve sleep in adults with primary insomnia without comorbidities.
results_summary: SSR significantly improved sleep quality (PSQI and ISI scores), sleep efficiency (SE%), and reduced fatigue compared to controls, with higher rates of insomnia remission (67% vs. 41%). No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Adults with persistent primary insomnia and no mental health or significant comorbidities in urban general practice settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the quality of reporting and variability in the application of sleep restriction therapy within insomnia intervention trials.
results_summary: The study found that 39% of papers did not report details on sleep restriction therapy parameters, and among those that did, there was significant variability in implementation. Only 7% of papers reported all parameters, indicating poor reporting and inconsistent application.
population_specificity: Insomnia intervention trials (88 studies included).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how partial sleep restriction (PSR) affects exertional heat strain and whether a daytime nap could mitigate its adverse effects.
results_summary: PSR increased rectal temperature, fatigue, sleepiness, and worsened psychomotor vigilance compared to normal sleep, but a nap significantly reduced fatigue, sleepiness, and improved vigilance.
population_specificity: Fourteen healthy subjects.
effective_dosage: Partial sleep restriction (4 hours) vs. normal sleep (7-8 hours).
study_duration: One night of sleep restriction followed by a daytime nap intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of weekend "catch-up" sleep on insulin sensitivity and metabolically active hormones in men with chronic sleep restriction.
results_summary: Three nights of "catch-up" sleep improved insulin sensitivity compared to sustained sleep restriction, with favorable changes in fasting insulin, c-peptide, leptin, PYY, and testosterone, while morning cortisol and LH remained unchanged. Targeted SWS suppression did not affect insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: 19 men (mean age 28.6 years, BMI 26.0 kg/m²) with a history of chronic sleep restriction during the workweek and regular weekend "catch-up" sleep.
effective_dosage: 10 hours, 6 hours, or 10 hours with SWS suppression per night for 3 nights.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether napping could mitigate the neuroendocrine and immune stress responses caused by sleep restriction.
results_summary: Napping normalized the increase in norepinephrine and interleukin-6 levels observed after sleep restriction and prevented elevated afternoon epinephrine and dopamine levels. A recovery night after napping was associated with reduced slow-wave sleep compared to no-nap conditions.
population_specificity: 11 healthy young men
study_duration: 1 night of sleep restriction (2 hours) followed by a day with or without naps, then a recovery night

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep extension could improve glucose metabolism in chronically sleep-restricted healthy adults.
results_summary: Sleep extension increased weekday sleep time and was associated with improved fasting insulin sensitivity, as well as correlated changes in glucose and insulin levels.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy non-obese volunteers (25 [23, 27.8] years old, 3 men).
effective_dosage: Participants were instructed to increase their time in bed by one hour per day.
study_duration: 6 weeks of sleep extension following 2 weeks of habitual sleep.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of sleep restriction therapy as a standalone intervention for treating chronic insomnia by reviewing existing literature.
results_summary: Sleep restriction therapy showed moderate-to-large improvements in sleep onset latency, wake time after sleep onset, and sleep efficiency, with a small improvement in total sleep time. However, evidence was insufficient to assess its impact on objective sleep variables or daytime functioning.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sleep restriction on laser evoked potential (LEP) habituation, pain thresholds, and suprathreshold pain perception.
results_summary: Sleep restriction reduced LEP amplitude and lowered cold pain thresholds, while increasing suprathreshold heat pain ratings temporarily. However, LEP habituation remained unchanged between groups.
population_specificity: 16 males and 17 females aged 18-31 years.
effective_dosage: Two nights of delayed bedtime with four hours of sleep (partial sleep deprivation) vs. nine hours of sleep.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physiological mechanisms involved in sleep restriction therapy for insomnia, focusing on changes in sleep variables, cortisol levels, and hyperarousal.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction therapy significantly decreased wake time, increased sleep efficiency, and reduced total sleep time. Objective measures also showed changes in sleep stages and decreased beta power, along with lower cortisol levels during treatment.
population_specificity: Five participants suffering from insomnia.
study_duration: Supervised weekly after initial in-lab application for two nights.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction therapy (SRT) reduces objective total sleep time, increases daytime somnolence, and impairs vigilance in patients with psychophysiological insomnia.
results_summary: The study found that SRT significantly improved subjective sleep outcomes and insomnia severity but reduced objective total sleep time during acute treatment, increased daytime sleepiness, and impaired vigilance, though these effects returned to baseline levels by 3 months.
population_specificity: Sixteen patients (10 female, mean age 47.1 years) with psychophysiological insomnia and reported total sleep time ≤ 6 hours.
effective_dosage: Single-component SRT over a 4-week protocol, with sleep monitored in the laboratory for specific nights during treatment.
study_duration: 4 weeks (acute phase), with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction therapy improves sleep quality in elderly individuals compared to a control group, while assessing its impact on sleep medication intake and daytime dysfunction.
results_summary: Sleep restriction therapy significantly improved sleep quality in the experimental group (PSQI score decreased from 14.21 to 11.26), but no significant differences were observed in sleep medication intake or daytime dysfunction between groups.
population_specificity: Elderly members of a center in Shiraz (n=38).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine adherence to 60-minute time-in-bed (TIB) restriction in older long and average sleepers and compare the effects of chronic TIB restriction between these groups.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. It will assess glucose tolerance, sleepiness, depressive symptoms, quality of life, cognitive performance, illness/accident incidence, and inflammation.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-80 years, divided into long sleepers (8-9 h/night) and average sleepers (6-7.25 h/night).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of recurrent sleep restriction on the plasma metabolome in adults with a familial risk of type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Sleep restriction increased concentrations of 12 amino acids and related metabolites, elevated fatty acids, bile acids, steroid hormones, and tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, while reducing circulating glucose, some monosaccharides, gluconate, and five-carbon sugar alcohols. The most pronounced metabolic signature was an elevation in plasma amino acids.
population_specificity: Eleven healthy adults (6M/5F; mean age 26 years; BMI 23.5 kg/m²) with parental history of type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of chronic sleep restriction on cocaine-seeking and cocaine-taking behaviors in rats during early acquisition of self-administration.
results_summary: Chronic sleep restriction enhanced fixed ratio responding and increased progressive ratio breakpoints in high drug-taking rats, indicating a heightened perceived incentive reward value of cocaine. Low drug-taking rats were unaffected by sleep restriction.
population_specificity: Rats (rodent model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction preferentially activates neural systems in response to unhealthy versus healthy foods.
results_summary: After sleep restriction, unhealthy foods elicited greater activation in brain regions linked to reward and food sensitivity compared to healthy foods. Additionally, food intake increased during sleep restriction, correlating with decreased activity in the right insula.
population_specificity: 25 normal-weight individuals who typically slept 7-9 hours per night.
effective_dosage: 4 or 9 hours in bed per night.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to profile changes in daytime functioning during Sleep Restriction Therapy (SRT) for insomnia, hypothesizing initial deterioration followed by improvements.
results_summary: The study found initial adverse effects (increased sleepiness/fatigue, decreased alert cognition) during week 1 of SRT, but by week 3, sleepiness/fatigue and negative mood decreased significantly, with positive mood showing a trend toward improvement. SRT also moderated alertness and sleepiness in therapeutic ways.
population_specificity: Nine patients with psychophysiological insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether small reductions in sleep duration over three weeks in a normal living environment affect insulin sensitivity and other metabolic parameters.
results_summary: Sleep restriction reduced sleep duration by about 1 hour 19 minutes daily and led to changes in insulin sensitivity, body weight, and leptin levels, though effects varied over time. No impact was observed on adiponectin or vascular function.
population_specificity: Nineteen healthy, young, normal-weight men
effective_dosage: Habitual bedtime minus 1.5 hours (sleep restriction group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction reduces insulin sensitivity in subcutaneous fat, a key peripheral tissue involved in energy metabolism.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (4.5 hours in bed) led to a nearly 3-fold increase in the insulin concentration required for half-maximal stimulation of phosphorylated Akt (pAkt), indicating reduced cellular insulin sensitivity. Total body insulin sensitivity also decreased significantly during sleep restriction compared to normal sleep (8.5 hours in bed).
population_specificity: Seven healthy adults (1 woman, 6 men) with a mean age of 23.7 years and mean BMI of 22.8 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 4.5 hours in bed (restricted sleep) vs. 8.5 hours in bed (normal sleep).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of recurrent sleep restriction on 24-hour blood glucose control during diet-induced weight loss in overweight and obese adults.
results_summary: Sleep restriction enhanced 24-hour insulin economy without compromising glucose homeostasis, reduced fasting blood glucose, increased fasting free fatty acids, and lowered total and LDL cholesterol concentrations. However, sleep-loss-related changes in counter-regulatory hormone secretion limited the utility of the IVGTT.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (3 females, 7 males; mean age 41 years; BMI 27.4 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relative efficacy of sleep restriction therapy as a component of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) in improving insomnia severity and sleep parameters.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction therapy significantly improved insomnia severity (Cohen's d = -0.45) and self-reported sleep continuity and quality, but no significant effects were observed on objective sleep parameters.
population_specificity: 15,351 participants (mean age 44.9 years, 70.1% female) with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia, including the role of behavioral techniques like sleep restriction.
results_summary: Both ACT and CBT significantly reduced insomnia severity with large effect sizes, though CBT showed superior short-term efficacy. ACT demonstrated delayed but comparable long-term benefits, even without behavioral techniques like sleep restriction.
population_specificity: 227 adults with insomnia
study_duration: 6 weekly group sessions, with follow-up at 6 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-dose aspirin (ASA) could reduce inflammatory responses caused by experimental sleep restriction.
results_summary: Low-dose ASA reduced IL-6 expression in monocytes, lowered CRP levels, and improved sleep efficiency during recovery after sleep restriction compared to placebo. It also decreased COX-1/COX-2 double-positive cells and reduced wake after sleep onset.
population_specificity: 46 healthy participants (19F/27M, age 19-63 years).
effective_dosage: 81 mg/day (taken daily in the evening at 22:00).
study_duration: 14-day at-home phase followed by an 11-day in-laboratory stay.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I), which includes sleep restriction, is delivered in randomized controlled trials for individuals with comorbid disordered sleep and persistent musculoskeletal pain.
results_summary: CBT-I consistently included sleep restriction and stimulus control, with additional components like cognitive therapy and sleep hygiene. The frequency and duration of sessions were largely consistent, but reporting on intervention delivery and content was inconsistent.
population_specificity: Individuals with comorbid disordered sleep and persistent musculoskeletal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how nocturnal sleep timing and duration influence daytime napping and vice versa, particularly in adolescents.
results_summary: Earlier wake times increased the likelihood and advanced timing of naps on school days, while longer naps shortened nocturnal sleep. On weekends, later bedtimes and wake times delayed nap timing, and later naps delayed bedtimes.
population_specificity: 153 adolescents (43.8% male, mean age 16.6 years) who napped at least occasionally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how sleep restriction influenced dietary intake in children and investigate the relationship between changes in time use and dietary intake.
results_summary: Sleep restriction led to increased energy intake, particularly from non-core foods, independent of changes in sedentary time and physical activity. Increased sedentary time was linked to higher non-core food intake, while increased MVPA was associated with higher core food intake.
population_specificity: 105 healthy children aged 8-12 years with normal sleep patterns.
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction involved turning lights off one hour later than usual for one week.
study_duration: One week per intervention (sleep restriction and sleep extension), separated by a washout week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an online behavioral self-help intervention, used alongside sleep restriction, could reduce insomnia severity and improve mood in individuals with acute insomnia, and if it could serve as a "sleep vaccination" for good sleepers.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced insomnia severity and improved mood in people with acute insomnia within one week, with effects lasting up to three months. No benefits were observed in good sleepers.
population_specificity: 344 participants (103 good sleepers and 241 with DSM-5 acute insomnia).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1 week, 1 month, and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the causal impact of sleep restriction on physical activity levels in young adults under real-world conditions.
results_summary: Sleep restriction reduced nightly sleep by an average of 92.65 minutes and led to a 7% reduction in average hourly physical activity, characterized by decreased intensity and increased sedentary behavior.
population_specificity: 146 young adults
effective_dosage: Restricted sleep (5-6 hr/night) vs. well-rested sleep (8-9 hr/night)
study_duration: Two separate weeks (one for each sleep condition) with a washout week in between

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how pain severity and interference impact the effectiveness of behavioral insomnia treatments (including sleep restriction) in women veterans.
results_summary: The study found no significant moderation effects of pain severity or interference on sleep improvements from baseline to post-treatment and 3-month follow-up, suggesting behavioral sleep interventions can be effective regardless of pain levels.
population_specificity: United States women veterans with comorbid pain and insomnia.
study_duration: Post-treatment and 3-month follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association of sleep restriction, as a component of CBT-I, with treatment outcomes for chronic insomnia disorder.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was identified as a critical component of CBT-I, associated with improved subjective sleep quality, sleep efficiency, and wake after sleep onset, with an incremental odds ratio for remission of 1.49 (95% CI, 1.04-2.13).
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 years and older with chronic insomnia disorder, both with and without comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of sustained adequate sleep versus insufficient sleep on cognitive performance in healthy adults.
results_summary: Adequate sleep (7-9 hours/night) improved working memory and response inhibition, while insufficient sleep (1.5 hours less than adequate) did not reach expected cognitive performance levels. The effects were consistent across tasks measuring working memory and inhibitory control.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (mean age 35.9 ± 4.9 years, 89% women, 52% non-White race/ethnicity) who regularly slept 7-9 hours/night.
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction of 1.5 hours less than habitual sleep (7-9 hours/night).
study_duration: Two 6-week intervention conditions separated by a 2-6 week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neurobehavioral impairments worsen during successive cycles of sleep restriction and recovery in young adults and whether a variable short sleep schedule mitigates these impairments compared to a stable one.
results_summary: The stable short sleep group showed faster vigilance deterioration in the second week of sleep restriction compared to the first, while the variable short sleep group did not. Both short sleep groups experienced attenuated subjective alertness and practice-based improvement in processing speed.
population_specificity: 52 healthy young adults (25 males, aged 21-28)
effective_dosage: Stable short sleep group: 6-hour time-in-bed (TIB) each night; variable short sleep group: 8-hour, 4-hour, 8-hour, 4-hour, and 6-hour TIBs across five nights; control group: 8-hour TIB each night.
study_duration: Two baseline nights followed by two cycles of "weekday" sleep manipulation and "weekend" recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the endorsement and applicability of sleep restriction as a component of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) in adults with chronic insomnia disorder.
results_summary: The study endorsed sleep restriction as a conditionally effective single-therapy component of CBT-I for chronic insomnia disorder, though multicomponent CBT-I was strongly recommended. The efficacy of sleep restriction was acknowledged, but standalone sleep hygiene education was not endorsed due to lack of evidence.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic insomnia disorder, with or without comorbid psychiatric and medical conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a two-stage model for defining stages of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) based on Sleep Restriction Therapy (SRT) progression and examine its association with baseline insomnia severity.
results_summary: The study proposed a parsimonious model for tracking CBT-I progression, which identified treatment patterns linked to baseline insomnia severity. The model may help improve understanding of CBT-I processes like adherence and optimal treatment component sequencing.
population_specificity: Participants from a prior randomized clinical trial (specific population details not provided in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how chronic sleep restriction influences eating patterns linked to overconsumption and explore associations between these patterns and diet quality under different sleep conditions.
results_summary: The study found that chronic short sleep increased eating frequency and negatively affected associations between meal timing variability and components of diet quality, providing insights into how insufficient sleep contributes to overconsumption and obesity.
population_specificity: 65 adults (47 females)
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction of -1.5 hours/night relative to screening
study_duration: Two 6-week conditions (adequate sleep and sleep restriction)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore neurocognitive functioning and treatment effects in individuals with comorbid insomnia and sleep apnea (COMISA), particularly examining the impact of sleep restriction as part of CBT-I.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (via CBT-I) was associated with poorer neurocognitive performance compared to baseline, though some improvements were noted in attention/vigilance and verbal memory. These effects may be temporary and linked to initial reductions in total sleep time.
population_specificity: Adults with comorbid insomnia and sleep apnea (n = 45; 51.1% female; mean age = 52.07 ± 13.29 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Hare Krishna Mantra Based Cognitive Therapy (HMBCT) combined with traditional cognitive-behavioral therapy techniques, including sleep restriction, in improving sleep quality for individuals with insomnia.
results_summary: The study found that HMBCT significantly improved sleep quality, with a 61% reduction in Epworth Sleepiness Scale scores and an 80% reduction in Insomnia Severity Index scores. Sleep restriction, as part of the combined therapy, contributed to these positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Participants from Hindu, Muslim, and Christian faiths diagnosed with insomnia using AASM criteria.
effective_dosage: Six 45-minute sessions of HMBCT per week, practiced in the evening on sleep recording days.
study_duration: Six weeks of treatment, with a one-week period before and after without intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of mild sleep deprivation on health-related quality of life (HRQOL) in healthy children without major sleep issues.
results_summary: The study found that even 39 minutes less sleep per night for one week significantly reduced several facets of HRQOL in children, including physical well-being, coping in a school environment, and social and peer support. Both parents and children reported greater sleep impairment during the day with sleep restriction.
population_specificity: 100 children aged 8 to 12 years in Dunedin, New Zealand, with no underlying medical conditions and parent-reported normal sleep (8-11 hours/night).
effective_dosage: Bedtimes were manipulated to be 1 hour later (sleep restriction) and 1 hour earlier (sleep extension) than usual.
study_duration: 1 week each for sleep restriction and sleep extension, with a 1-week washout in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia, particularly focusing on sleep restriction as a key determinant of treatment success.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was identified as the strongest determinant of insomnia treatment success, with cognitive interventions further enhancing the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia. The study also highlighted the need for future research on physiological changes post-therapy, such as hyperarousal and brain activity.
population_specificity: Individuals with insomnia (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of behavioural therapy, including sleep restriction, for improving sleep and mental health in healthcare night workers with shift work disorder.
results_summary: The behavioural therapy (BT-SWD) significantly reduced daytime insomnia severity and increased daytime total sleep time compared to controls, with large effect sizes. Improvements in sleepiness, anxiety, and depression were also maintained at follow-up.
population_specificity: Healthcare night shift workers (mean age 34 years, 77% women) diagnosed with shift work disorder.
effective_dosage: Not specified (therapy included sleep restriction, stimulus control, and fixed sleep periods in the dark).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impacts of fatigue (linked to sleep restriction) on healthcare practitioners' clinical practice and wellbeing and propose methods to mitigate these effects.
results_summary: The study found that fatigue among healthcare staff, caused by long hours and night shifts, is linked to poorer patient outcomes, longer hospital stays, and increased risks of accidents, errors, and health issues for practitioners. It highlights the lack of fatigue management policies in healthcare compared to other safety-critical industries.
population_specificity: Healthcare practitioners

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine how changes in sleep duration influence energy intake and eating behavior in children.
results_summary: Sleep restriction led to increased daily energy intake, particularly from noncore and ultraprocessed foods, and altered eating behaviors like emotional overeating and undereating. The effects were more pronounced in the per-protocol analysis.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-12 years who met current sleep guidelines (8-11 hours/night).
effective_dosage: Sleep was manipulated by 1 hour earlier (extension) or later (restriction) than usual bedtime.
study_duration: Each sleep condition lasted 7 consecutive nights, separated by a 1-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolic biomarkers indicative of sleepiness and its behavioral outcomes by comparing different sleep-wake schedules.
results_summary: The study investigated changes in metabolic profiles and performance metrics under sleep restriction and deprivation but did not report specific findings in the abstract. It focused on establishing a candidate biomarker panel for sleepiness.
population_specificity: 24 participants in a controlled, randomized, crossover clinical study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (sleep conditions varied by wake/sleep regimes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of explicitly behavioural interventions, including sleep restriction, for treating insomnia in older adults, with secondary goals of assessing impacts on mood and daytime functioning.
results_summary: Sleep restriction, both alone and as part of multicomponent interventions, significantly improved subjectively measured sleep outcomes, though actigraphic or polysomnographic results showed smaller or no effects. Multicomponent therapies demonstrated larger effects (median Hedge's g = 0.55), but no significant improvements in anxiety measures were observed.
population_specificity: Older adults (>60 years) with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential contribution of behavioral activation (BA) elements, including sleep restriction, to the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral treatment for insomnia (CBT-I).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that BA elements, such as sleep restriction, may contribute to the efficacy of CBT-I, though the independent impact of BA on insomnia treatment remains under-researched. It implies that BA, whether incidental or extensively deployed, likely plays a role in CBT-I's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore rheumatoid arthritis patients' experiences with cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) and how its components were incorporated into sleep management.
results_summary: Patients experienced CBT-I as a bodily and cognitive process, leading to improved sleep through changed mindset and behavior, though some found sleep restriction challenging. The therapy was generally perceived as beneficial despite initial difficulties.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (N=11) who participated in a randomized controlled trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify baseline characteristics associated with increases in total sleep time (TST) after cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), which includes sleep restriction.
results_summary: Patients with more severe self-reported sleep difficulties and lower baseline sleep duration showed greater improvements in TST after CBT-I. No other baseline variables (e.g., age, sex, polysomnography data) were associated with TST changes.
population_specificity: 80 participants from a randomized controlled trial assessing acute and maintenance CBT-I.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of daytime napping on sports performance in physically active individuals, both with and without partial-sleep deprivation.
results_summary: The majority of studies reported favorable effects of daytime napping on sports performance, with longer nap durations (~90 min) showing more significant advantages. Only one study found no significant impact, possibly due to methodological differences and shorter nap duration.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 18 years or older, including physically active and athletic populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize available research on the association between short sleep duration and higher levels of aggression.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 60 studies showed a pooled correlation estimate of -0.16 (95% CI -0.19, -0.12) between sleep duration and aggression, indicating a modest but statistically significant inverse relationship. The study included observational and experimental designs with a total of 76,761 participants.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from meta-analysis of diverse studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore patient use and feedback of a brief sleep resource, including sleep restriction, for improving sleep in individuals with anxiety or depression.
results_summary: The study found that a brief sleep resource incorporating sleep restriction was used by patients and provided feedback, suggesting potential utility in addressing comorbid insomnia without requiring a full insomnia-specific ICBT course.
population_specificity: Patients seeking transdiagnostic internet-delivered cognitive behavior therapy (T-ICBT) for anxiety or depression with sleep difficulties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a multimodal shift-work intervention on perceived fatigue, sleepiness, physical and mental health, sleep parameters, and absenteeism in shift workers.
results_summary: The study expected significant improvements in sleepiness, fatigue, sleep parameters, absenteeism, and overall health in the intervention group, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract. The intervention combined healthy scheduling, education, and information campaigns for shift planners.
population_specificity: Shift workers (specifically drivers of a public transport company)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a smartphone app (SPA) providing brief personalized therapy, including sleep restriction, for insomnia among workers.
results_summary: The SPA significantly improved insomnia severity (ISI scores) in the intervention group compared to controls, with notable improvements in physical fatigue scores among ISI-8-insomniacs.
population_specificity: Japanese workers with mild insomnia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (personalized prompt messages and therapy components).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of insomnia symptoms in teachers, associated biopsychosocial factors, and the efficacy of interventions, including sleep restriction, for managing these symptoms.
results_summary: One online intervention incorporating sleep restriction, stimulus control, and rumination reduction techniques showed evidence of efficacy in addressing insomnia symptoms in teachers. The study found that 36-61% of teachers reported insomnia symptoms, with factors like being female, classroom violence, and depression being associated.
population_specificity: School teachers (kindergarten through high school) from 15 countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality, content, evidence base, and potential therapeutic benefit of mobile health applications targeting insomnia, including those featuring sleep restriction.
results_summary: Among 53 evaluated mobile health applications, 16 (30%) included sleep restriction. Most applications had moderate overall quality, but scientific evidence was limited, with only one randomized controlled study identified.
population_specificity: Users of mobile health applications targeting insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia, including sleep restriction, as a first-line treatment for insomnia in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia, which includes sleep restriction, is more effective than medications for long-term management of insomnia in older adults. It recommends avoiding medications like benzodiazepines and antidepressants for this population.
population_specificity: Older adults with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the percentage of participants who met or exceeded baseline total sleep time (TST) after cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia, including sleep restriction.
results_summary: By the end of acute treatment, 45% of participants reached or exceeded baseline TST, increasing to 86% by 24 months. Only 17% achieved a 30-minute TST increase initially, rising to 58% over time.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic insomnia (n = 80).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how adherence to cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), including sleep restriction, was measured, evaluate predictors of adherence, and determine if adherence was associated with treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to CBT-I, including sleep restriction, was inconsistently measured across studies. Better pre- and post-session sleep, greater psychosocial support, and fewer dysfunctional beliefs about sleep predicted greater adherence. Only insomnia severity index scores post-treatment were consistently predicted by adherence, but this was limited to a few adherence measures.
population_specificity: Adults with insomnia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the epidemiological evidence linking sleep duration to obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and explore plausible mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction is associated with changes in energy homeostasis, insulin resistance, and β-cell function, and established short sleep duration as a risk factor for obesity and T2DM. Additionally, short sleep duration was linked to less weight loss following lifestyle interventions or bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: General population, with specific focus on individuals at risk for obesity and T2DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between sleep duration and food consumption, energy intake, anthropometric characteristics, and appetite-regulating hormones through randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was found to significantly increase energy intake, fat intake, body weight, appetite, hunger, eating occasions, and portion size, while protein and carbohydrate consumption, total energy expenditure, and respiratory quotient remained unaffected. Serum leptin, ghrelin, and cortisol concentrations were not influenced by sleep duration.
population_specificity: Children or adolescents (7 studies) and adults (43 studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of an anonymous online CBT-I program (including sleep restriction) versus a waiting-list control group and face-to-face CBT-I for improving sleep outcomes in shift workers.
results_summary: The study expects both online and face-to-face CBT-I interventions to improve self-reported depression, insomnia symptoms, sleep quality, and daytime sleepiness compared to the control group, though specific results are pending.
population_specificity: Shift workers with sleep issues.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included psychoeducation, sleep restriction, stimulus control, relaxation techniques, and individual feedback via four e-mail contacts).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (weekly sleep diaries were used during the intervention and waiting period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sleep deprivation during pregnancy on maternal behavior in animals through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analyses found no significant impact of sleep deprivation on maternal behavior in rats, contradicting previous clinical studies. The study concluded a lack of translational applicability of animal models for this research.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the skeletal consequences of sleep and circadian disruption, focusing on bone turnover markers, bone mineral density (BMD), and fracture risk.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction and circadian disruption negatively alter bone turnover markers, potentially explaining lower BMD and increased fracture risk observed in night shift workers. Abnormal sleep duration and obstructive sleep apnea were inconsistently associated with skeletal health risks.
population_specificity: Human intervention study (small sample) and broader literature review including night shift workers and individuals with abnormal sleep durations or obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mild sleep restriction increases "eating in the absence of hunger" (EAH) in children.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in energy intake from EAH between sleep restriction and extension conditions. However, a learning effect was observed, with children eating less during the preload phase and more in the ad libitum phase in the second week.
population_specificity: 105 healthy children aged 8-12 years with normal sleep duration (∼8-11 hours/night).
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction involved going to bed 1 hour later than usual bedtime.
study_duration: 2 intervention weeks separated by a 1-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of telephone-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), which includes sleep restriction, compared to an education-only control in improving sleep, pain, and fatigue in older adults with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Telephone CBT-I significantly improved insomnia severity, fatigue, and transiently reduced pain compared to the control group, with sustained benefits at 12-month follow-up. Sleep restriction, as part of CBT-I, demonstrated clinically meaningful and statistically significant improvements in sleep outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults (60+ years) with moderate to severe osteoarthritis pain and insomnia.
effective_dosage: Six 20-30 minute telephone sessions over 8 weeks.
study_duration: 8 weeks (intervention), with follow-up at 2 months and 12 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Brief Behavioral Treatment for Insomnia (BBTi), which includes sleep restriction, on metacognition in older adults with insomnia.
results_summary: BBTi selectively improved metacognitive ratings of performance relative to same-age peers, with consistent improvements over time. Both BBTi and the control group showed general improvements in other metacognition variables (quality, satisfaction, compared to own ability).
population_specificity: Older adults with insomnia (N = 62, mean age = 69.45 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (BBTi included psychoeducation, sleep hygiene, stimulus control, sleep restriction, relaxation, and review/maintenance over 4 weeks).
study_duration: 4 weeks of treatment, with follow-up assessments at 2 weeks post-treatment and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on how sleep restriction impacts the risk of type 2 diabetes in adolescents, focusing on mechanisms like energy balance, insulin sensitivity, and behavioral changes.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was associated with increased hunger, appetite, and food intake, leading to positive energy balance and weight gain. It also reduced insulin sensitivity and physical activity, collectively elevating the risk of type 2 diabetes in adolescents.
population_specificity: Adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 20-minute nap, caffeine, or caffeine before a nap on performance and muscle damage in sleep-deprived athletes.
results_summary: Napping improved repeated-sprint performance and antioxidant defense, while caffeine increased muscle damage without enhancing performance. Combining caffeine with a nap was more beneficial for sprint performance than either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Nine male, highly trained judokas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of acceptance and commitment therapy-based behavioral intervention for insomnia (ACT-BBI-I) with cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), both incorporating sleep restriction.
results_summary: Both ACT-BBI-I and CBT-I significantly improved sleep patterns, insomnia severity, anxiety, beliefs about sleep, and psychological flexibility, with effects maintained at 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Forty-five adults with chronic insomnia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (sleep restriction was part of the behavioral protocols).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical significance and outcomes of Sleep Restriction as a nonpharmacological treatment for insomnia in the elderly.
results_summary: The study found that Sleep Restriction, along with other behavioral interventions, showed clinically significant results in improving sleep outcomes for elderly individuals with insomnia. It was one of the few interventions with rigorous evidence supporting its effectiveness in this population.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of sleep extension to mitigate obesity risk and cardiometabolic dysfunction, and to assess the feasibility of various sleep extension approaches.
results_summary: Sleep extension partially rescued cardiometabolic dysfunction in some studies, and preliminary findings suggest it may improve glycemic control, decrease blood pressure, and enhance weight loss, though results were inconsistent. Adequate nightly sleep appears necessary for optimal health.
population_specificity: Habitually short sleepers and individuals with obesity or cardiometabolic dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sleep restriction therapy as a single-component treatment for chronic insomnia disorder in adults.
results_summary: The study suggests that clinicians use sleep restriction therapy as a single-component treatment for chronic insomnia disorder in adults, though the recommendation is conditional, indicating the need for clinical judgment and consideration of patient preferences.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic insomnia disorder

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sleep health, particularly sleep restriction, on dietary intake in adults.
results_summary: The study found that partial sleep restriction (≤5.5 hours per night) increased energy intake, particularly from fat, but did not significantly affect protein or carbohydrate intake. The meta-analysis included 15 studies, with most interventions focusing on sleep duration rather than timing.
population_specificity: Adults (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction to ≤5.5 hours per night.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic effects of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), including sleep restriction, on insomnia in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: CBT-I, incorporating sleep restriction, showed medium-to-large effect sizes in reducing insomnia and improving sleep quality, with benefits persisting post-intervention and at follow-ups (up to 12 months). The effect sizes were consistent across different delivery formats and comparison designs.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors with insomnia.
study_duration: Varied (follow-ups at post-intervention, within six months, and at 12 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep restriction causally increases somatic complaints in healthy adolescents.
results_summary: Adolescents slept two fewer hours during the Insufficient Sleep condition and reported significantly greater frequency and severity of somatic complaints compared to the Sufficient Sleep condition. The findings suggest that restricting sleep to levels common in adolescence causally increases somatic complaints.
population_specificity: Healthy adolescents aged 14-18 years (n=30).
effective_dosage: 6.5 hours in bed (Insufficient Sleep) vs. 9.5 hours in bed (Sufficient Sleep) for five nights each.
study_duration: Three weeks (including a sleep stabilization week and two experimental conditions with washout periods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if insomnia patients with objective sleep disturbance respond differently to cognitive and behavioral treatments, including sleep restriction therapy (SRT), and whether these therapies affect objective sleep measures.
results_summary: The study found that SRT did not produce clinically meaningful effects on polysomnography (PSG) sleep parameters. Patients with lower pretreatment sleep efficiency had lower remission rates after active treatment. Reductions in nocturnal cognitive arousal were associated with decreased sleep latency but not wake after sleep onset.
population_specificity: 113 postmenopausal women (mean age 56.40 ± 5.34 years) with menopause-related insomnia disorder.
study_duration: Not specified (assessed at pretreatment, posttreatment, and six-month follow-up)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how patients with depression experience and adhere to CBT-I, including sleep restriction, and identify factors influencing treatment adherence.
results_summary: Participants found behavioral methods (including sleep restriction) effective but challenging, while cognitive methods were harder to adopt due to fatigue and cognitive issues. Adherence was influenced by support systems, treatment format, and side effects of medication.
population_specificity: Twelve patients with depression and comorbid insomnia.
study_duration: Six sessions of CBT-I (duration not specified)
interactions: Side effects of medication were noted as impeding adherence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of home-based sleep interventions, including sleep restriction, based on cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) in improving sleep outcomes for cancer survivors.
results_summary: Both the intervention group (with sleep restriction) and the control group (without sleep restriction) showed improvement in sleep outcomes, but there was no significant difference between the two groups. The results suggest that sleep restriction, as part of a broader CBT-I intervention, may not significantly enhance efficacy compared to other behavioral approaches.
population_specificity: Adult cancer survivors with trouble falling asleep or falling back to sleep on 3 of 7 days, excluding those with diagnosed sleep or mental health disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between sleep patterns, particularly sleep restriction, and academic performance in adolescents, and to evaluate the effects of modified school start times on sleep outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that impaired sleep quality and quantity due to chronic sleep restriction or disrupted sleep-wake cycles are associated with decreased learning ability and compromised daytime functioning in adolescents. Modified school start times showed potential to improve sleep patterns and related outcomes.
population_specificity: Adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of total and partial sleep loss on neural correlates of fear conditioning, extinction learning, and extinction recall in healthy young adults.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (SR) enhanced fear-related activity and diminished extinction-related activity compared to normal sleep (NS), while sleep deprivation (SD) delayed engagement of extinction learning. SR activated salience and motor areas during extinction recall, differing from NS and SD patterns.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults (56.3% female, age 24.8 ± 3.4 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (sleep restriction and deprivation conditions only).
study_duration: One night of intervention (normal sleep, sleep restriction, or sleep deprivation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the extent and scope of studies investigating the association between dietary intake and sleep health, including sleep restriction, and to identify gaps in research methodologies and population representation.
results_summary: The review found that most dietary interventions focused on supplements like caffeine, while sleep interventions primarily examined partial sleep restriction under 5.5 hours per night, with few studies on total sleep deprivation. Future research should explore broader aspects of diet and sleep health.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the 24-hour and time-of-day effects of sleep restriction on cortisol, luteinizing hormone, and testosterone in young and older men.
results_summary: Sleep deprivation significantly reduced testosterone secretion, particularly in older men, and increased afternoon cortisol in older men, while also reducing luteinizing hormone in the morning in both age groups. The study found age-dependent differences in the effects of sleep restriction on hormonal regulation.
population_specificity: Healthy men aged 18-30 (n=17) and 60-80 (n=18) years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (sleep deprivation involved complete nighttime wakefulness).
study_duration: Single overnight intervention (prospectively randomized crossover study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the bedtime restriction component of CBTi exacerbates daytime sleepiness in patients with comorbid moderate and severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and insomnia.
results_summary: CBTi initially increased daytime sleepiness (15% increase in ESS scores) in the first week but returned to pretreatment levels afterward, while sleep parameters gradually improved. No differences in daytime sleepiness changes were found between CBTi and control groups or OSA-severity groups, and higher pretreatment ESS scores correlated with greater ESS reduction during CBTi.
population_specificity: 145 patients with untreated physician-diagnosed OSA (apnea-hypopnea index ≥15) and psychologist-diagnosed insomnia (ICSD-3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between poor sleep hygiene, sleep deprivation, and increased accident risk, particularly in driving.
results_summary: The study found that self-reported sleepiness at the wheel and inappropriate line-crossings are strong predictors of accident risk. It suggests that simple questions about near misses and sleepiness should be used to assess fitness to drive, rather than relying solely on the Epworth sleepiness scale.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population, likely drivers)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of sleep opportunity (restriction vs. extension) on asthma symptoms and lung function in adolescents.
results_summary: Short sleep opportunity (6.5 h/night) resulted in lower morning FEV1, increased asthma symptoms, and higher albuterol use compared to long sleep opportunity (9.5 h/night), with a trend toward greater negative impact on daily life. No differences were found in weekly lung function or inflammation measures.
population_specificity: 54 adolescents (12-17 years, 69% female, 65% Caucasian) with asthma.
study_duration: Five nights per sleep condition (Short and Long), preceded by a sleep stabilization week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of face-to-face (FtF) and chat-based brief psychotherapy for insomnia, which included sleep restriction as a component.
results_summary: Both FtF and chat-based treatments improved sleep quality compared to the waiting list control, with chat-based treatment slightly outperforming FtF. The study suggests chat-based communication may enhance treatment adherence and patient autonomy.
population_specificity: 73 patients diagnosed with insomnia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (sleep restriction was part of a broader three-session intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of acupuncture and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I), which includes sleep restriction, in reducing insomnia severity among cancer survivors.
