results_summary: CBT-I was more effective than acupuncture in reducing insomnia severity posttreatment, with both treatments producing clinically meaningful improvements that lasted up to 20 weeks. CBT-I showed greater efficacy for specific subgroups, such as males, whites, highly educated individuals, and those without baseline pain.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors (mean age 61.5 years, 56.9% women)
effective_dosage: Not specified for sleep restriction alone (CBT-I included multiple components)
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with follow-up until 20 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to address key issues in the real-world delivery of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), including its implementation, appropriate candidates, and quality care measurement.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the underuse of CBT-I despite its status as a first-line treatment for chronic insomnia and identifies targets for future research to improve its real-world implementation.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic insomnia disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-i), including sleep restriction, in school-aged children and adolescents.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that CBT-i techniques, including sleep restriction, show promising effects for treating insomnia in younger age groups, though more research is needed to confirm specific characteristics and models.
population_specificity: School-aged children and adolescents with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating bed partners into cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTI), which includes sleep restriction, improves treatment adherence and completion.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for sleep restriction alone, but it evaluated adherence to sleep restriction as part of CBTI and compared outcomes between partner-assisted and traditional individual CBTI. Results will clarify the role of adherence in treatment effectiveness.
population_specificity: 120 clients with insomnia, including those who share a bed with a partner.
effective_dosage: Not specified for sleep restriction alone; interventions consisted of seven weekly 1-hour sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the bi-directional relationship between sleep and diet, and their combined impact on cardiovascular health, with a focus on the role of the gut microbiome.
results_summary: Sleep restriction leads to unhealthy food choices and increased energy intake, while adherence to a Mediterranean diet predicts healthier sleep. The gut microbiome may underlie these relationships, though more research is needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population inferred)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how chronic sleep restriction (CSR) affects the magnitude and duration of sleep inertia-related cognitive performance impairments.
results_summary: Performance impairments upon awakening were ~10% worse in CSR conditions compared to Control, persisting throughout sleep inertia, especially during biological nighttime awakenings. Subjective sleepiness did not differ between groups despite objective performance differences.
population_specificity: 26 healthy participants.
effective_dosage: Sleep opportunity equivalent to 5.6 hr per 24 hr day for CSR conditions, 8 hr for Control.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether a brief CBT-I intervention, including sleep restriction, could effectively improve depressive symptoms in community-dwelling older adults with insomnia.
results_summary: The brief CBT-I intervention, which included sleep restriction, showed a statistically significant improvement in depressive symptoms (p < .01) with a small effect size (Cohen's d = 0.34). The results suggest modest effectiveness for improving depression in this population.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with insomnia symptoms of varying severity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how cumulative mild partial sleep deprivation (eliminating 1 hour of sleep over 6 nights) impacts working memory, sustained attention, response inhibition, and decision making.
results_summary: Sleep restriction negatively affected working memory capacity but did not impact sustained attention, response inhibition, or decision making. The placebo group showed improved working memory performance, while the sleep-restriction group did not.
population_specificity: 93 adults (mean age 24.3 years; 46 men, 47 women) with no reported sleep, behavioral, or medical issues.
effective_dosage: Elimination of 1 hour of sleep relative to baseline habitual sleep duration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mild sleep deprivation increases energy intake in the absence of hunger in children.
results_summary: The study investigated how mild sleep restriction influences eating behavior and activity patterns in children, comparing sleep restriction (1 hour later bedtime) and sleep extension (1 hour earlier bedtime) over two weeks. Results were not explicitly stated in the abstract, but the study design suggests a focus on measuring energy intake, dietary habits, and activity levels under different sleep conditions.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-12 years with normal reported sleep duration of 8-11 hours per night.
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction by 1 hour later bedtime and sleep extension by 1 hour earlier bedtime for seven nights each.
study_duration: 2 weeks (1 week per condition, separated by a washout week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to address knowledge gaps regarding the minimum sleep needed for militarily relevant performance and the impact of chronic sleep restriction on health and psychological well-being in military personnel.
results_summary: The study highlights ongoing efforts to develop individualized sleep/alertness management systems for military personnel and investigates the prevalence, etiology, and treatment of sleep disorders in this population, but does not provide specific outcomes on sleep restriction effects.
population_specificity: Military personnel

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the translatability and effectiveness of CBT-I programs, including sleep restriction therapy, when implemented in primary care and community settings.
results_summary: Sleep restriction therapy, as part of CBT-I programs, showed small to moderate post-treatment effect sizes for sleep efficiency, sleep onset latency, and wake time after sleep onset, but no significant effect on total sleep time. Intervention heterogeneity limited full evaluation of the programs' impact.
population_specificity: 1625 participants across 12 studies, likely including individuals with insomnia (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cognitive-behavioral treatment for insomnia (CBTi) could reduce headache frequency in adults with chronic migraine.
results_summary: The combined analysis showed that CBTi reduced monthly headache frequency by 6.2 days more than the control group, with a 97.5% probability of being at least 2.7 days better. The findings suggest CBTi is effective for reducing headaches in chronic migraineurs with comorbid insomnia.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic migraine and comorbid insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the application of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia, including sleep restriction, in improving sleep and pain interference in people with chronic pain.
results_summary: Cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia, which includes sleep restriction, was found to be efficacious for improving sleep initiation, maintenance, perceived sleep quality, and reducing pain interference in daily functioning for chronic pain patients. Physical therapist-led interventions were also deemed effective for low back pain.
population_specificity: People with chronic pain, particularly those with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia, including sleep restriction, as a first-line treatment for older adults.
results_summary: Cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia, which includes sleep restriction, was found to be more effective than medications for long-term management of insomnia in older adults. The abstract highlights its recommendation as a first-line treatment.
population_specificity: Older adults with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of moderate sleep restriction on body weight, body composition, and metabolic variables in individuals undergoing caloric restriction.
results_summary: Sleep restriction led to less proportion of fat mass loss compared to caloric restriction alone, despite similar overall weight loss. It also affected metabolic variables differently, with reduced resting respiratory quotient in the caloric restriction group and reduced fasting leptin concentration in the sleep restriction group.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction of approximately 1 hour on five nights per week, with ad libitum sleep on the other two nights

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence supporting the effectiveness of CBT for insomnia (CBTi), including sleep restriction, in improving sleep outcomes such as remission, sleep onset latency, wakefulness after sleep, sleep efficiency, and sleep quality.
results_summary: The study found that CBTi, which includes sleep restriction, is effective in improving various sleep parameters in adults with insomnia, including older adults and adolescents. The therapy was highlighted as a safe and effective alternative to pharmacotherapy.
population_specificity: General adult population, older adults, and adolescents with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of behavioral therapy for insomnia (BT-I) and cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), which includes sleep restriction, on depressive and fatigue symptoms.
results_summary: Individual face-to-face CBT-I showed significant effects on depressive symptoms (d = 0.34) but not on fatigue symptoms, with high heterogeneity between studies. The source of heterogeneity remained unidentified despite sensitivity analyses.
population_specificity: Adults with insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of non-pharmacologic treatments, including sleep restriction, for managing insomnia.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that sleep restriction, among other non-pharmacologic treatments, has been shown to be efficacious for insomnia management. Pharmacological treatments are noted as adjuvants, but no ideal drug is identified.
population_specificity: Not specified (general insomnia population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of in-person and unguided Internet-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTi), including sleep restriction, against a minimal contact control condition in military personnel.
results_summary: Both Internet and in-person CBTi significantly improved sleep efficiency, sleep onset latency, awakenings, wake time after sleep onset, insomnia severity, and dysfunctional beliefs about sleep compared to the control. In-person treatment showed better results on sleep quality and dysfunctional beliefs than Internet treatment, though technical issues affected sleep restriction titration for some participants.
population_specificity: Active duty US Army personnel at Fort Hood, Texas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) delivered via a fully automated mobile phone app, including sleep restriction, compared to a waitlist control group.
results_summary: The app significantly improved insomnia severity and sleep efficiency, with effects retained at a 3-month follow-up. The improvements were comparable to those seen in web-based treatments.
population_specificity: Participants in the Netherlands with relatively mild insomnia disorder.
effective_dosage: Not specified (app included sleep diary, relaxation exercise, sleep restriction exercise, and sleep hygiene education).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the causal impact of sleep restriction on energy intake, energy expenditure, and body weight, as well as its effects on weight loss and appetite regulation.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction hinders weight management, increases energy intake, and negatively impacts weight regulation, while sleep extension may improve appetite control.
population_specificity: Not specified (general clinical intervention study context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between sleep disruption, circadian misalignment, and metabolic dysfunction, including their impact on energy metabolism, caloric intake, and glucose regulation.
results_summary: The study found that insufficient sleep and circadian misalignment contribute to metabolic dysregulation by promoting excess caloric intake, reduced energy expenditure, and disrupted glucose metabolism, increasing the risk of obesity and diabetes. These factors represent modifiable risk factors for metabolic disease prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: General population, with emphasis on individuals with insufficient sleep or shift work schedules.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore barriers and facilitators to the use of an adjunctive computerized cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CCBT-I) program, including the impact of sleep restriction, among depressed patients in a psychiatric clinic.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was identified as a major problem for persistence by more than 15% of participants, though it was a key active behavioral intervention. Clinician support and coordination with clinical treatment were highlighted as important for program adherence.
population_specificity: Depressed patients in a psychiatric clinic setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term sleep loss affects gut microbiota composition and metabolic outcomes, such as insulin sensitivity.
results_summary: The study found that two nights of partial sleep deprivation altered gut microbiota composition (increased Firmicutes:Bacteroidetes ratio and changes in specific bacterial families) and reduced insulin sensitivity, but did not affect beta diversity or short-chain fatty acid concentrations.
population_specificity: Nine normal-weight men.
effective_dosage: Sleep opportunity of 02:45-07:00 h (partial sleep deprivation) vs. 22:30-07:00 h (normal sleep).
study_duration: Two nights per condition (partial sleep deprivation and normal sleep).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether total sleep deprivation (TSD) augments perceived pain during cold pressor testing (CPT) and if this effect is sex-dependent.
results_summary: The study found that TSD significantly increased perceived pain during CPT, with higher mean and peak pain scores compared to normal sleep. The effect was similar in both men and women.
population_specificity: 14 men and 13 women, nonsmokers with no history of cardiovascular disease, autonomic dysfunction, asthma, or diabetes; women were tested during the early follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.
study_duration: Testing sessions (NS and TSD) were separated by approximately one month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate alternatives to benzodiazepines for treating insomnia and anxiety in older adults, including nonpharmacological approaches like sleep restriction-sleep compression therapy.
results_summary: The study highlights sleep restriction-sleep compression therapy as a viable nonpharmacological alternative for treating insomnia in older adults, alongside cognitive behavioral therapy and other pharmacological agents. It emphasizes the risks of benzodiazepines and barriers to discontinuation.
population_specificity: Older adults (specific age range not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationships between objectively and subjectively measured sleep duration and various health indicators in children and youth aged 5-17 years.
results_summary: Longer sleep duration was associated with lower adiposity indicators, better emotional regulation, better academic achievement, and better quality of life/well-being. The evidence was mixed or limited for cognition, harms/injuries, and cardiometabolic biomarkers.
population_specificity: Apparently healthy children and youth aged 5-17 years from 40 different countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of experimental sleep manipulation (including sleep restriction, extension, and improvement) on cognitive functioning in adolescents.
results_summary: Partial sleep restriction had small or no effects on cognitive functioning, while sleep deprivation showed consistent decrements in psychomotor vigilance. Sleep extension and improvement contributed to working memory enhancement, and sleep after learning improved memory consolidation.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 10-19 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a nonclinician-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) program, which included sleep restriction, in improving sleep outcomes for older adults with chronic insomnia.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in sleep onset latency, total wake time, sleep efficiency, and insomnia severity compared to controls at posttreatment, 6-month, and 12-month follow-ups. No significant differences were found in objective sleep efficiency, depressive symptoms, or quality of life.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling veterans aged 60 and older with chronic insomnia (N = 159).
effective_dosage: Five-session manual-based CBT-I program, including sleep restriction, delivered individually or in small groups.
study_duration: Five sessions, with follow-up assessments at 6 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of telephone-based cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), which includes sleep restriction, compared to menopause education control (MEC) in improving sleep quality in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women with insomnia and hot flashes.
results_summary: Telephone-based CBT-I significantly improved insomnia symptoms and sleep quality compared to MEC, with sustained benefits at 24 weeks. Sleep restriction, as part of CBT-I, led to greater improvements in sleep latency, wake time, and sleep efficiency, though it did not affect hot flash frequency.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal or postmenopausal women aged 40 to 65 years with moderate insomnia symptoms and 2 or more daily hot flashes.
effective_dosage: Six telephone sessions over 8 weeks, with weekly electronic sleep diaries and behavioral homework.
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with follow-up assessments at 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between sleep deprivation and insulin sensitivity in adolescents, comparing those with sleep deprivation (<8 hours/night) to those with adequate sleep (≥8 hours/night).
results_summary: Adolescents with sleep deprivation had lower insulin sensitivity, higher BMI, and greater central fat distribution compared to those with adequate sleep. Sleep deprivation remained an independent predictor of these outcomes after controlling for age and sex.
population_specificity: 615 adolescents aged 10 to 19.9 years with a BMI at or above the fifth percentile for age and sex.
study_duration: Cross-sectional study (data collected from June 29, 2011, to December 3, 2014)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Sleep Restriction Therapy for insomnia modifies physiological arousal, measured via plasma cortisol concentrations and core body temperature.
results_summary: Sleep Restriction Therapy reduced insomnia severity and core body temperature but unexpectedly increased early morning cortisol levels. No changes were observed in pre-sleep or early-night cortisol.
population_specificity: Eleven patients with chronic and severe Psychophysiological Insomnia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a brief behavioral insomnia intervention, including stimulus control and sleep restriction, for reducing headache frequency in adults with chronic migraine and comorbid insomnia.
results_summary: Both CBTi (including sleep restriction) and control interventions reduced headache frequency, with CBTi showing larger, enduring improvements in sleep parameters and headache frequency post-treatment. CBTi also significantly improved total sleep time, sleep efficiency, and insomnia severity compared to the control.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic migraine and comorbid insomnia (mean age 30.8 years, 90.3% female, 80.6% white).
effective_dosage: Three 30-minute biweekly sessions of CBTi or control treatment, with daily practice of instructed skills.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between sleep restriction and weight gain, particularly focusing on its role in obesity and eating behaviors.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction is associated with weight gain, increased food intake, and a preference for energy-dense foods, with snacking and meal frequency also rising. It highlights the need for further research on screen exposure's impact on sleep in children and youth.
population_specificity: Children and youth (pediatric population)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate napping as a countermeasure for sleep deprivation and its potential as a public health tool to mitigate negative consequences of sleep debt.
results_summary: The study found that napping may positively impact physiological functions such as cognitive performance, stress, immune function, and pain sensitivity, and could reduce accidents and cardiovascular events. However, the impact of napping and the specific sleep stages involved still require further evaluation, especially in populations with chronic sleep debt like shift workers.
population_specificity: General public and clinical settings, with specific mention of night and shift workers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of trained pharmacists delivering behavioral interventions, including sleep restriction, for improving insomnia severity in patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a greater reduction in Insomnia Severity Index compared to the control group, but the difference was not statistically significant when clustering effects were accounted for. The study suggests potential benefits of pharmacist-delivered behavioral interventions for insomnia.
population_specificity: Patients with insomnia (mean age 53.7 ± 18.4, 72% females) recruited through community pharmacies in New South Wales, Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether therapist support enhances the effectiveness of cognitive behaviorally based bibliotherapy for insomnia by increasing patient involvement in key treatment methods, including sleep restriction.
results_summary: Therapist support significantly improved treatment outcomes, with patient involvement in sleep restriction, sleep compression, and stimulus control fully mediating the effect. The supported condition explained 68.4% of the total therapeutic effect.
population_specificity: 89 participants with insomnia (mean age 49.1, 77% female, predominantly well-educated and Caucasian).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of sleep restriction on mood improvement in depressed patients and its persistence after recovery sleep.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was found to improve mood in depressed patients, but the benefits typically disappeared after recovery sleep. The abstract suggests overlapping neural mechanisms between sleep and mood regulation.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder accompanied by sleep disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleep differs after consumption of a controlled diet versus an ad libitum diet and if dietary intake during ad libitum feeding relates to nocturnal sleep.
results_summary: Sleep duration did not differ between controlled and ad libitum diets, but ad libitum eating reduced slow wave sleep and increased sleep onset latency. Higher fiber intake predicted more restorative sleep, while higher saturated fat and sugar intake led to lighter, less restorative sleep with more arousals.
population_specificity: 26 normal-weight adults (30-45 years old) habitually sleeping 7-9 hours per night.
study_duration: 5 nights per phase (habitual sleep phase analyzed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), including sleep restriction, for improving insomnia symptoms and comorbid outcomes in patients with psychiatric or medical conditions.
results_summary: CBT-I, including sleep restriction, significantly improved insomnia remission rates (36.0% vs. 16.9% in controls) and sleep parameters (medium to large effect sizes for sleep efficiency, sleep onset latency, wake after sleep onset, and sleep quality). Comorbid symptoms showed small to medium improvements, with greater effects in psychiatric populations.
population_specificity: Adults meeting diagnostic criteria for insomnia with concomitant psychiatric or medical conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-i), which includes sleep restriction, on overnight sleep measures in adults with chronic insomnia.
results_summary: CBT-i significantly improved sleep onset latency (19.03 minutes), wake after sleep onset (26.00 minutes), and sleep efficiency (9.91%), with sustained benefits over time. Total sleep time showed modest improvement (7.61 minutes), though the confidence interval included zero.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic insomnia (mean age 56 years; 64% female), excluding those with comorbid medical, sleep, or psychiatric disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (multimodal CBT-i included at least 3 components: cognitive therapy, stimulus control, sleep restriction, sleep hygiene, and relaxation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between short sleep duration (SSD) and weight gain, exploring potential mechanisms and implications for obesity treatments.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction increases food intake beyond the energetic costs of wakefulness, potentially due to disrupted appetite-regulating hormones or altered brain mechanisms. Additionally, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and obesity interact, with weight loss improving OSA severity and possibly promoting further weight loss.
population_specificity: Individuals with short sleep duration and those with obesity or obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the effect of 8 days/8 nights of partial sleep restriction on endothelial function in healthy humans.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (5.1 hours/night) significantly impaired endothelial function, measured by flow-mediated vasodilatation (FMD), compared to the control group (6.9 hours/night). No change was observed in non-flow mediated vasodilatation (NFMD) in either group.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction to two-thirds normal sleep time (5.1 hours/night)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a guided internet-based recovery training (GET.ON Recovery) incorporating sleep restriction and other CBT-I techniques for reducing insomnia severity and work-related strain in employees.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced insomnia severity (d=1.45, P<0.001) compared to the waitlist control, with strong clinical relevance (NNT <2 for reliable change). It also improved mental detachment from work and recreational behavior, sustained at 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: German teachers with clinical insomnia complaints (ISI ≥15) and work-related rumination (cognitive irritation subscale ≥15).
study_duration: Post-test and 6-month follow-up (intervention duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of cognitive-behavioral therapy, including sleep restriction, as a nonpharmacologic treatment for insomnia in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that cognitive-behavioral therapy, which includes sleep restriction, is the criterion standard for treating insomnia in cancer patients, though other methods like exercise and integrative medicine showed varying results without firm efficacy recommendations.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer experiencing sleep disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on adolescent sleep patterns, factors contributing to chronic sleep loss, and its health-related consequences.
results_summary: The study found that chronic sleep loss in adolescents leads to daytime impairments, increased risks of depression, obesity, and drowsy driving accidents, and suggests later school start times as a potential mitigation strategy.
population_specificity: Adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biological mechanisms linking sleep disturbance, including sleep restriction, to immune responses and disease risks such as infectious diseases, cardiovascular disease, cancer, and depression.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction negatively impacts both adaptive and innate immunity, increasing risks for infectious diseases and chronic conditions like cardiovascular disease and depression, while also highlighting potential interventions to improve sleep health.
population_specificity: General population with focus on immune and disease-related outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a military version of brief behavioral treatment for insomnia (BBTI-MV) compared to an information-only control (IC) on insomnia, sleep quality, and daytime symptoms of anxiety and depression in combat-exposed Veterans.
results_summary: Both BBTI-MV and IC showed clinically significant improvements in insomnia, with BBTI-MV demonstrating greater improvements in sleep and higher rates of treatment response and remission. The findings suggest both approaches may be viable in a stepped-care treatment model for insomnia in Veterans.
population_specificity: Combat-exposed Veterans of Operations Enduring/Iraqi Freedom or Operation New Dawn (OEF/OIF/OND), predominantly male (85%) and white (77.5%), with a mean age of 38.4 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (behavioral intervention, not a supplement)
study_duration: Four weeks (two in-person sessions and two telephone contacts)

study_goal: To examine the adverse metabolic effects of sleep disruption and explore preventive measures against obesity and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was associated with decreased insulin sensitivity, glucose tolerance, and increased risk of obesity and type 2 diabetes. It also led to increased food intake, reduced physical activity, and weight gain despite higher energy expenditure.
population_specificity: General population, with focus on individuals with sleep disorders, diabetes, and obesity.

study_goal: The abstract does not specifically address Sleep Restriction; it discusses general approaches to treating insomnia and related sleep disorders.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Sleep Restriction; it outlines treatment strategies for acute and chronic insomnia and mentions specific conditions like restless legs syndrome and sleep apnea.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of insomnia patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between serum testosterone levels and sleep, including the effects of sleep restriction on testosterone.
results_summary: Sleep restriction lowers testosterone if it occurs in the first half of the night, but recovery from sleep disruption is impaired in older rodents. In men with OSA, low testosterone is linked to obesity rather than OSA itself.
population_specificity: Men (including those with obstructive sleep apnoea) and rodents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if lifestyle recommendations, including sleep restriction, could improve both depressive symptoms and metabolic profiles in patients with depression.
results_summary: The study found that patients receiving hygienic-dietary recommendations, including sleep restriction, showed fewer cases of metabolic syndrome at six months compared to the control group, suggesting combined lifestyle interventions may benefit mental and physical health.
population_specificity: Depressive patients, some with metabolic syndrome at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether circadian misalignment in shift work has intrinsic adverse metabolic effects independently of sleep loss.
results_summary: Sleep restriction reduced insulin sensitivity and increased inflammation in both groups, with the effects doubling in males under circadian misalignment. The study suggests circadian misalignment in shift work may independently increase diabetes risk and inflammation.
population_specificity: 26 healthy adults.
effective_dosage: Sleep restricted to 5 hours per day.
study_duration: 11 days (3 days with 10-hour bedtimes, followed by 8 days of sleep restriction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between sleep restriction, circadian rhythm disruption, and testosterone levels, including the effects of conditions like OSA and exogenous testosterone.
results_summary: Sleep restriction and circadian disruption may reduce testosterone levels, but evidence is equivocal. OSA has no direct effect on testosterone after adjusting for age and obesity, but weight loss reliably increases testosterone. Testosterone replacement improves sleep quality, while abuse disrupts sleep architecture.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of sleep-related conditions and testosterone effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of treatment response to brief behavioral treatment of insomnia (BBTI), including the role of sleep restriction, in older adults with insomnia.
results_summary: Higher baseline anxiety, depression, poorer sleep quality, and longer sleep latency predicted better response to BBTI, while longer baseline sleep duration predicted greater likelihood of remission. Short sleepers at baseline were less likely to achieve remission, possibly due to the sleep restriction component.
population_specificity: Older adults with insomnia (67% female, mean age 72.54 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate actigraphy for detecting sleep and wakefulness compared to polysomnography (PSG) under controlled sleep laboratory conditions, including during sleep restriction studies.
results_summary: The study found high sensitivity (0.965) and accuracy (0.863) for actigraphy in detecting sleep, but low specificity (0.329) for detecting wakefulness. Actigraphy underestimated wakefulness after sleep onset (WASO) when WASO was high (>30 min/night) but was unbiased when WASO was low (<30 min/night).
population_specificity: Young and older adults, healthy individuals, chronic primary insomniac patients, and night-workers (n = 77, age 35.0 ± 12.5, 30F).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sleep restriction on metabolic health, including its association with obesity and type 2 diabetes risk factors.
results_summary: Sleep restriction was linked to increased food intake, higher cortisol levels, reduced insulin sensitivity, and greater susceptibility to energy-dense foods, suggesting it may contribute to obesity and type 2 diabetes.
population_specificity: Adults and children who are habitual short sleepers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sleep curtailment on 24-hour energy expenditure (EE) and respiratory quotient (RQ) under controlled meal conditions.
results_summary: Short sleep (4 h/night) significantly increased 24-hour EE by ~92 kcal (~5%) compared to habitual sleep (8 h/night), but did not affect EE during scheduled sleep or waking episodes, nor did it alter RQ. The findings suggest that short sleep may contribute to weight gain primarily through increased energy intake rather than changes in energy expenditure.
population_specificity: Ten females aged 22-43 years with a BMI of 23.4-27.5 kg/m².
study_duration: 3 days per sleep condition, with a 4-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of MPO-dependent LDL oxidation (Mox-LDL) in the pathophysiology of atherosclerosis and its association with conditions like sleep restriction.
results_summary: The study found that Mox-LDL contributes to inflammation, foam cell formation, and increased thrombus risk, linking it to atherosclerosis-related conditions, including sleep restriction. However, specific effects or mechanisms of sleep restriction were not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of atherosclerosis-related conditions).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the effect of 8 days/8 nights of sleep restriction on caloric intake, activity energy expenditure, and circulating levels of leptin and ghrelin.
results_summary: Sleep restriction led to a significant increase in caloric intake (+559 kcal/d) without changes in activity energy expenditure or leptin and ghrelin levels. The findings suggest that increased caloric intake without compensatory energy expenditure may contribute to obesity under long-term sleep restriction.
population_specificity: Participants in a hospital-based clinical research unit (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Sleep restriction to two-thirds of normal sleep time for 8 days/8 nights.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between sleep duration and hypertension in women, assessing whether shorter sleep duration (≤5 hours) increases hypertension risk.
results_summary: The study found that women sleeping ≤5 hours had a significantly higher prevalence and incidence of hypertension, particularly in younger women (<50 years), with obesity acting as a partial mediator. No significant mediation or effect modification was observed for diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, shift work, snoring, menopause, or hormone therapy.
population_specificity: Women from the Nurses' Health Study I (1986, 2000) and Nurses' Health Study II (2001).

study_goal: The researchers sought to summarize the metabolic consequences of shortened sleep and subsequent recovery sleep, focusing on obesity and diabetes.
results_summary: Epidemiological studies suggest links between shortened sleep and future obesity/diabetes, while experimental data indicate probable associations with altered glucose metabolism and appetite dysregulation. The review highlights potential metabolic consequences of chronic sleep restriction.
population_specificity: General population (not specified beyond epidemiological and experimental data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate the Glasgow Sleep Impact Index (GSII) to measure sleep-related daytime dysfunction and quality of life impairment in insomnia patients, and assess its sensitivity to change post-sleep restriction therapy.
results_summary: The GSII demonstrated excellent face and construct validity, was sensitive to change post-behavioral treatment (p<0.001; Cohen's d≥0.85), and improvements correlated with reductions in insomnia severity (r=0.28-0.56). Commonly cited impairment areas included energy/motivation, work performance, and cognitive functioning.
population_specificity: 108 patients (71% female; mean age=45) meeting Research Diagnostic Criteria for Insomnia Disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether recurrent sleep curtailment reduces physical activity in adults at risk for type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Sleep restriction (5.5 hours vs. 8.5 hours) led to a 31% reduction in total activity counts, a 24% decrease in moderate-plus-vigorous activity, and increased sedentary behavior. These declines correlated strongly with reduced subjective vigor.
population_specificity: Eighteen healthy adults (9 females, 9 males, mean age 27) with a parental history of type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of a self-help cognitive behavioral intervention, including sleep restriction, in improving sleep quality in older adults with chronic insomnia symptoms associated with long-term conditions.
results_summary: The self-help intervention significantly improved sleep quality, insomnia severity, and sleep efficiency post-treatment and at 3- and 6-month follow-ups, with moderate effect sizes. However, it had no effect on daytime fatigue levels.
population_specificity: Self-referred individuals aged 55 to 87 with long-term conditions and chronic insomnia symptoms.
effective_dosage: Six consecutive booklets delivered weekly, providing structured CBT-I advice, including sleep restriction.
study_duration: 6 weeks (intervention), with follow-ups at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of single-component (SCT, SRT) and multicomponent (MCI) behavioral treatments for insomnia in older adults, assessing both short-term and long-term outcomes.
results_summary: Sleep restriction therapy (SRT) showed significant improvement in subjective sleep measures compared to the control group, with medium to large effect sizes. Treatment gains were maintained at follow-up for key sleep outcomes, though multicomponent therapy (MCI) had a higher remission rate.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 68.9 years, 64.2% women) with chronic primary insomnia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (behavioral intervention administered over 6 weeks).
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-ups at 3 months and 1 year posttreatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of immune-circadian interactions in depression and how chronotherapeutics and antidepressants might modulate these processes.
results_summary: The study suggests a bi-directional relationship between immune processes and chronobiological disruption in depression, with potential chronobiotic effects of antidepressants and chronotherapeutics mediated via the neuroimmune system. Further research is needed to clarify these mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (review paper, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a constructive worry (CW) intervention to behavior therapy (BT) involving sleep restriction and stimulus control improved outcomes for insomnia patients.
results_summary: Both BT and BT + CW improved subjective sleep estimates, insomnia severity, worry, and dysfunction, but BT + CW showed larger reductions in insomnia severity and worry at multiple time points. No significant differences were found for total wake time or total sleep time between the two conditions.
population_specificity: 22 patients with primary insomnia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of sleep curtailment in metabolic and endocrine alterations and its potential link to obesity.
results_summary: The study found that sleep restriction leads to decreased glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, and leptin levels, while increasing cortisol, ghrelin, hunger, and appetite, potentially contributing to obesity. It also suggested that sleep restriction may increase food intake and fatigue, reducing energy expenditure.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from epidemiological and laboratory-based studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic consequences of chronic sleep restriction and its potential role in obesity and related morbidities.
results_summary: The study found that sleep loss triggers neuroendocrine, metabolic, and behavioral adaptations that increase food intake and conserve energy, potentially undermining weight loss efforts in obesity-prone individuals. These effects may be maladaptive in modern environments with abundant food and sedentary lifestyles.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese individuals, particularly those attempting weight loss through caloric restriction and increased physical activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of partial sleep restriction on neuronal activation in response to food stimuli.
results_summary: The study found greater overall neuronal activity in response to food stimuli after restricted sleep compared to habitual sleep, with increased brain activity in reward-related areas like the putamen, nucleus accumbens, thalamus, insula, and prefrontal cortex. These results suggest that reduced sleep may increase susceptibility to food stimuli and propensity to overeat.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy, normal-weight (BMI 22-26) men and women (26 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate an adaptive-duration version of the Psychomotor Vigilance Test (PVT-A) to improve its practicality in operational and clinical settings while maintaining accuracy in assessing behavioral alertness under sleep deprivation.
results_summary: The PVT-A demonstrated high accuracy (95.7% correct classifications), sensitivity (93.7%), and specificity (96.8%) in classifying performance during sleep deprivation, with an average test duration of 6.4 minutes. The adaptive strategy effectively reduced test time without compromising the ability to detect moderate impairment.
population_specificity: Seventy-four healthy subjects (34 women), aged 22 to 45 years.
effective_dosage: Acute total sleep deprivation (33 hours awake) and chronic partial sleep deprivation (5 nights of 4 hours time in bed).
study_duration: 33 hours for TSD, 5 days for PSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of normal sleep versus one night of sleep restriction on monotonous driving performance in CPAP-treated OSA patients and healthy controls.
results_summary: After normal sleep, CPAP-treated OSA patients and controls showed similar driving performance. However, after sleep restriction, OSA patients had significantly worse driving impairment, shorter safe driving times, and underestimated their sleepiness compared to controls.
population_specificity: 19 CPAP-treated male OSA patients (aged 50-75) and 20 age-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review cognitive impairments caused by sleep disruption in rodent models and explore neurobiological mechanisms underlying these deficits.
results_summary: The study found that sleep disruption in rodents leads to deficits in attention, learning, memory, emotional reactivity, and higher-order cognitive functions, similar to human studies. It highlights neuroplastic changes and brain mechanisms potentially responsible for these cognitive impairments.
population_specificity: Rodent models (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)-based self-help, including sleep restriction, is effective for treating insomnia, particularly in individuals with co-morbid problems, and if adding brief therapist support enhances its efficacy.
results_summary: Both self-help groups (with and without therapist support) showed significant improvements in sleep onset latency and remission rates compared to the waiting list control, with therapist support yielding higher remission rates. Gains were maintained at three-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 133 media-recruited adults with insomnia (mean sleep difficulty duration of 11.8 years), 92.5% of whom had co-morbid problems (e.g., allergy, pain, depression).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included sleep restriction as part of a broader CBT-based self-help program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT), including sleep restriction, for treating Behavioural Insomnia of Childhood in school-aged children.
results_summary: CBT significantly improved sleep latency, wake after sleep onset, sleep efficiency, and reduced problematic sleep associations and child-reported anxiety, with effects maintained at 6-month follow-up. Total sleep time did not show significant improvement.
population_specificity: 42 school-aged children (7-13 years, 18 female, 24 male) with Behavioural Insomnia of Childhood.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an online CBT-I program, including sleep restriction, could effectively improve insomnia symptoms in cancer survivors.
results_summary: The Internet-based CBT-I group showed significant improvements in insomnia severity, sleep efficiency, sleep onset latency, soundness of sleep, restored feeling upon awakening, and general fatigue compared to the control group. Effect sizes for sleep variables and related outcomes ranged from small to large.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors with insomnia (n=28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of oxidative stress, including sleep restriction, in the development of insulin resistance and diabetes.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that sleep restriction is one of the lifestyle factors contributing to oxidative stress, which can lead to insulin resistance and diabetes, but does not provide specific findings on sleep restriction's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of oxidative stress mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a combined sleep hygiene education and behavioral approach program, including sleep restriction, on sleep quality in workers with insomnia.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant improvement in sleep quality (PSQI score decreased by 1.0), while the control group's sleep quality worsened (PSQI score increased by 0.9). The difference between groups was statistically significant (1.9, 95% CI: 0.6 to 3.4).
population_specificity: Employees at a design engineering unit in Japan with insomnia (Athens Insomnia Scale ≥6 points).
